name: Jeff Duncan
content:
So - this morning, the House Republican Conference voted to remove Congresswoman Liz Cheney from her post as Conference Chair. You may wonder, why?

After the January 6th events at the United States Capitol, which saw former President Trump Impeached; saw fencing and razor wire erected by Speaker Pelosi around the Capitol complex (fencing is still up around the Capitol); and the National Guard called in as a deterrent against any future riotous protests (they are still here, btw), Representative/Chairwoman Cheney (R-WY) made comments on the events, about former President Trump and had voted to Impeach.

I believe she had the right to cast a vote of conscience during the impeachment process. That vote is between her and the constituency in Wyoming. She also has the right to have an opinion about former President Trump, as well as an opinion about the events of January 6th. Again, that is, and will be, between her and the Wyoming voters.

So, here is the rub which caused the movement for change within the Republican Conference: Liz Cheney was Chairwoman of the Conference. When she spoke, as a leader, she should be cognizant that her words might be construed as reflecting the opinion/will of the whole Republican Conference. They did not. In addition, she was defiant and showed no humility when a large majority of the Conference asked her to clarify, retract or differentiate between personal feelings and those of Republicans as a whole.

I believe, as we see too often in “the Swamp,” that Representative Cheney lost touch with the average American voter - those men and women who work hard, mow their own lawns, and maybe even enjoy writing their name on a dollar bill and sticking on the wall of a bar somewhere.

Those voters may have cringed over how former President Trump said things at times. But those same men and women really liked what he had done and was doing to return America to its rightful role as a world-leading nation versus the global apologetic nation we saw under the Obama Administration (and are seeing return under Joe Biden).

In her statement today, Representative Cheney tries to define the Republican Party, conservatism, and how she views the Constitution. She also tries to paint former President Trump as someone who doesn’t believe in the Constitution. She seems to fail at an understanding that her words, as Chairwoman, were construed to be those of the Conference.

Let me say this to Liz (whom I really like as a person, would have supported as a WY Senator had my dear friend Cynthia Lummis not ran for, and won, that Senate seat:

Conservatism is about limited government, free markets and individual liberties. Conservatives believe in a strong military, as you do. But Conservatives also are frustrated after 20 years of war. Conservatives are tired of the Washington spending as well as the intrusion on our liberties and federalism as our Founders envisioned. Conservatives, and most Republicans of all flavors liked what the Trump POLICIES were doing for our nation, our families, our businesses, and our communities.

So - if we are going to attempt to redefine the GOP, we would do good to remember that those policies and a return to Liberty are important for, not only the success of the nation, but for success of our GOP.

I am deeply disturbed by the ransomware attack that shut down the Colonial Pipeline, an important source of gasoline. As a former member of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, I have long been a supporter of increased investment in our cybersecurity infrastructure. As a nation, we have underinvested in cybersecurity which has left us vulnerable to foreign hackers.

While the Colonial Pipeline expects to restart services soon, the Biden Administration is working diligently to increase the supply of gas to Georgia. The Department of Transportation has issued a temporary hours of service exemption to provide greater flexibility to motor carriers and drivers transporting gasoline, diesel, jet fuel and other refined petroleum products. Additionally, the Administration supported Georgia’s waiver to allow higher weight limits for fuel tank trucks.

I will continue to closely monitor the situation and support efforts at the federal, state, and local levels to provide relief to those most affected by this attack.

Older Americans deserve full access to the resources they need so they may live and age with dignity. Sadly, the COVID-19 pandemic has exposed the major cracks in our long-term care system that have unfairly impacted older Americans and the services that they depend on. The American Rescue Plan addresses these disparities by investing in our seniors.

The American Rescue Plan makes critical investments to meet the health and economic needs of our seniors, such as improving mental health care, caregiver support, and increased access to vaccines.

For Florida's seniors, the plan includes:

$56.6 million for meals for older adults in Florida;
$34.7 million for Home and Community Based Services
$3.3 million for health promotion and disease prevention in Florida;
$12 million to help family caregivers support their loved ones; and
$755,148 to safeguard the health and welfare of residents in Florida’s long-term care facilities.

name: Jerry Moran
content:
Last week, Gene Schmidt’s life was celebrated, and today I want to honor his legacy by sharing the impact he had on our state and country. After experiencing the tragic loss of his daughter, Stephanie, in 1993, Gene and his family dedicated themselves to advocating for crime victims and their families.

Gene and his wife, Peggy, traveled the country speaking out for victims’ rights, organized the Speak Out for Stephanie foundation to create greater public awareness regarding sex offenders and created the Stephanie Schmidt Task Force for Victims’ Rights to develop recommendations for changes in the law. Due to their efforts, the Stephanie Schmidt Sexual Predator Act was signed into law and Kansas became a pioneer for victims’ rights legislation.

Gene and Peggy have been nationally recognized for their relentless activism in Stephanie’s memory through the National Crime Victims’ Service Award and the Attorney General’s Distinguished Service Award.

I was thankful to know him and am sending my sincere condolences to his family. Read more about Schmidt’s work in this story recognizing the 20th anniversary of Stephanie’s death: https://www.kansascitymag.com/girl-interrupted/
